text: america's top military general has
warned that a russian invasion of
ukraine would be horrific and would lead
to significant casualties general mark
miley described the build-up of 100 000
russian troops near ukraine's border as
the largest since the cold war but the
u.s defense secretary lloyd austin said
conflict could still be avoided through
the use of diplomacy russia denies it
plans to invade ukraine
here in the uk downing street has
announced plans for the prime minister
to travel to eastern europe next week as
britain steps up diplomatic efforts to
help resolve the crisis boris johnson is
also expected to have a call with
russian president vladimir putin simon
jones has this report
preparing for a possible war britain is
already bolstering ukraine's defenses
ukrainian soldiers are being trained to
use anti-tank missiles provided by the
uk
boris johnson says he's determined to do
all he can to avoid bloodshed he'll
visit the region in the coming days and
he'll call president putin with the
message russia needs to step back and
engage diplomatically
at a meeting here at the ministry of
defense top officials outlined a range
of options to counter what's being
described as growing russian aggression
in the region one option would see more
british troops sent to reinforce nato
defenses that's something boris johnson
will consider over the weekend
the us-2 is sending equipment to ukraine
and some soldiers will shortly be moved
to eastern europe the u.s says the
russian troop buildup on ukraine's
border is the largest since the cold war
given the type of forces that are raid
the ground maneuver forces the artillery
the ballistic missiles the air forces
all of it packaged together
if
that was unleashed on ukraine it would
be significant it would be horrific it
would be terrible and it's not necessary
and we think a diplomatic outcome
is the way to go here
but russian training exercises continue
president putin reportedly told the
french president that he had no plans
for an offensive but he said the u.s and
nato had failed to address russia's main
demands for nato forces to withdraw from
eastern europe boris johnson there was
warning that if diplomacy fails
thousands of lives could be lost
simon jones bbc news
for more on the build-up of russian
forces along the ukrainian border i've
been speaking to mikey kay a retired
senior raf officer and former adviser to
britain's ministry of defence i began by
asking him what russia would have to
gain from an invasion of ukraine
i think the answer in terms of what they
stand to gain from at samantha is is not
a lot i mean i've done multiple combat
tours in iraq and afghanistan
kosovo both under the nato guys um and
also a masters in war fighting from
king's college and i can tell you right
now that
uh you know when warfare occurs
diplomacy has failed um warfare is the
is the blunt tool that is used when
uh you know talks fail and diplomacy
doesn't work so
and people just get killed unnecessarily
so so
that's not what anyone wants
um i think there's a really interesting
component of gabriel's report here in
terms of
him articulating what they were allowed
to have access to
and that's very much in conventional
terms we're talking about russian tanks
we're talking about anti-tank missiles
well i think there's a there's a lot we
can learn from contemporary history here
in terms of the way that russia operates
and the way that warfare is evolving and
it's not on a conventional basis
it's on a it's on a hybridized basis
and i think what we should be really
looking at in terms of what putin's next
move is going to be
is what his moves have been
in in recent past and two good areas to
look at are the way that he
intervened in crimea uh and why he
intervened in crimea and that was
because of a military strategic
objective which were the two bases or
the bases in sebastopol which is um on
the crimean peninsula and they gave him
access both to naval power and air power
to the to the black sea so that was
absolutely critical for putin to to keep
that and then the other interesting um
case study is the way that he putin
intervened in syria and just turned up
one day in western syria and latakia
with russian jets at one of the air
bases there and again you know the
strategic principle there was the
prevention of in my opinion was the
prevention of terrorism moving
northwards through the north caucus so
um i think if putin was going to have
gonna move on eastern ukraine he would
have moved already and then we've got to
ask herself what are the strategic
objectives by doing what he is doing at
the moment you've also got to remember
that if any warfare does occur in
eastern ukraine samantha that the it's
not just about warfare there's a there's
a holding component here you know and to
be able to hold a piece of territory you
need far more military apparatus than
being able to invade a piece of
territory and we've seen that
in iraq and afghanistan and quite
frankly it hasn't gone well
